user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_DeleteNode:
```c
void UtList_DeleteNode(UtListNode_t *DeleteNode)
{
    UtList_Extract(DeleteNode);

    /* non-data/header nodes shouldn't be free()'ed */
    if (DeleteNode->Data != NULL)
    {
        free(DeleteNode);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
UtList_Extract(DeleteNode);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation can be determined from the single call UtList_Extract(DeleteNode) alone because this fragment does not invoke any <string.h> functions. The call itself does not violate Rule 21.17. A violation would occur only if the implementation of UtList_Extract uses string.h functions incorrectly — for example, doing memcpy(DeleteNode->Data, src, n) with n greater than the destination object size, strcpy(DeleteNode->Data, src) where src is longer than the destination buffer, or calling strlen on a non-terminated buffer so that the function reads past the object bounds. In such implementation cases Rule 21.17 would be violated.
